author: John Davidson
title: Apple TV: the Appy future of viewing
text:
Apple has finally overhauled its Apple TV platform That one feature could be a huge boon for TV subscription viewers, who often subscribe to two or three different services and have to search each of them when they're looking to watch a certain program.
Another feature of the Siri integration is a voice command that lets the view say "What did he say" to the remote control, and the set top box will automatically rewind the show 15 seconds and momentarily turn on the subtitles.
The main new feature of Apple TV is the remote control, which uses Bluetooth 4.0 and has a small trackpad which gives users gesture control over their TVs. A swipe during a show displays information about the show, for instance, and users can quickly scrub backwards and forwards through a show through another gesture.
The remote control also has a gyroscope and accelerometer, making it useful as a games controller and (presumably, though Apple never demonstrated this) allowing it to work a little like LG's Magic Remote, which can be waved in the air to give mouse-like control of smart TV features.
 Australian pricing has yet to be announced, but in the US the new Apple TV will be $US149 for a model with 32 gigabytes of storage, and $US199 for a 65 gigabyte model.
